title: Why did the Islamic world experience a resurgence after the Mongol conquest of Baghdad in 1258? - Quora

response.answer_text: It may surprise you that the Ottoman Turks, responsible for the ‘second golden age’, the resurgence of Islam from the Renaissance to early modernity, were indirect descendants of the Mongols of 1258. The descendants of the people who burned down the Baghdad library, expanded the borders of Islamic world to it’s greatest extent. At the time of Genghis Khan, the mongols were not particularly religious. They worshipped something like Buddhism, but they never enforced their belief on the people they subjugated; they were actually rather tolerant of other religions and allowed their subjects to practice any faith they wanted. Indeed, when the Ilkhanate burned down Baghdad and conquered the Islamic world, they treated believers of all Abrahamic faith equally. By the late 1200’s however, the rulers of the Khanate converted to Islam, partly to position themselves closer to the people they conquered. As a result, they became good Muslim rulers by enforcing taxes on Christians and Jews, rebuilding mosques, and launching wars against heathens in the name of Islam. In essence, after nearly destroying Islam, they sponsored it’s rebirth. Even after the Mongols were replaced by other nomadic people, the lasting influence of Islam was felt by other would-be conquerors in Central Asia who would war in the name of Islam.

Islamic world started to follow scolastic religious leaders like Gazzali instead logical thinking , science , free thinking , Islamic science replaced with ascetic education .This is the real reason , not some library burned in Bagdad .Blaming others will not change the fact .
